descriptionHow: Facing Tonal, take a handle in each hand and take a large step back behind the end of the Tonal arms. Take a large step forward with one leg, plant the foot firmly on the floor and lower down until both knees are bent 90 degrees and the back knee is just above the floor. Pressing through the heel of the front leg, power up and back to a standing position and switch sides.
descriptionWhy: A forward lunge movement with greater quad action & knee extension.

name: Alternating Goblet Reverse Lunge
descriptionHow: Hold the handle at the strap with thumbs wrapped around the top and place it in front of the chest. Stand tall at the end of Tonal’s arm. Reach one leg back, keeping the other foot planted on the floor, and lower down until both knees are bent 90 degrees and the back knee is just above the floor. Press the floor away from you, using the glute of the front leg to power back up to start and switch sides.
descriptionWhy: A great option for our goblet lunges. Higher reps are possible with the short rests on each side.

name: Resisted Deep Lunge
descriptionHow: Take the handle in one hand and bring the opposite leg forward about a foot behind Tonal’s arm. Reach the opposite leg back long and anchor the ball of the foot in the floor. With feet hip distance, lower down by driving the front knee forward over your toes, while keeping the back leg straight and strong. Think escalator not elevator as lower down. Pressing through the heel of the front foot, power back up to stand and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: Deeper than a normal lunge, this version is a good movement to test & improve ankle dorsiflexion + knee flexion/extension.

name: Bodyweight Alternating Reverse Lunge
descriptionHow: Stand with feet hip distance apart, arms at your sides. Keep one leg planted on the floor as you reach the other leg back and lower down until both knees are bent 90 degrees and the back knee is just above the floor. Push the floor away with the front leg, arms moving in opposition and then switch legs.
descriptionWhy: Movement regression from the jump lunges and a higher volume option than standard bodyweight lunges.

name: Bodyweight Alternating Step Up
descriptionHow: Place one foot on top of the bench ensuring that no part of the foot is hanging off the edge. Press your heel through the bench to stand upright, driving your opposite knee upwards to hip height. Step down with control, and repeat on the other side.
descriptionWhy: An alternating step up variation meant to induce a heart rate response, activate your glutes, and improve coordination.

name: Bodyweight Alternating Curtsey Lunge
descriptionHow: Starting in a standing position, step one foot behind and across the midline of the body, lowering to the ground by bending both knees so that your trailing knee finishes directly behind your front heel and your lead-leg knee tracks in alignment with your middle toes. With a tall posture, drive through your front heel and push off the back toes to return to the starting position. Repeat by alternating legs for the duration of the set.
descriptionWhy: An alternating variation to the curtsey lunge, this move strengthens the glutes and quadriceps with three-dimensional movement.

name: Reverse Lunge to Step Up
descriptionHow: Start standing tall, with the bench a half-step in front of you. Step one leg back, lowering your knee toward the ground behind you until your front thigh is parallel with the ground. Press through your front foot to stand and immediatly step the working side onto the bench. Finish the movement by pressing through the bench with the working foot, driving the opposite knee towards the chest at the top. From the top position, lower back to the ground, continuing immediately into the next reverse lunge and step up with the same leg for the duration of the set before switching.
descriptionWhy: A complex movement to strengthen glutes and quads, you'll also develop cardiovascular and metabolic capacity with each set.

name: Bodyweight Alternating Lateral Lunge
descriptionHow: From a standing starting position, step out wide to one side, keeping your trailing leg straight and feet parallel with toes forward. As you land, continue into a lunge by driving your hips down and back into the space above your leading heel. Drive back through the outside of the landing foot to return to starting position. Repeat to the opposite side, alternating sides for the duration of the set.
descriptionWhy: This move develops mobility and strength through the hips and groin, and builds cardiovascular and metabolic capacity when done with high intensity intent.

name: Barbell Front Racked Reverse Lunge
descriptionHow: Place the barbell on top of the shoulders until it’s just barely touching the front of the neck. Cross your arms to hold the bar and stand in between the Tonal arms. Reach one leg back, keeping the other foot planted on the floor, and lower down until both knees are bent 90 degrees and the back knee is just above the floor. Press the floor away from you, using the glute of the front leg, to power back up to start. Repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: Knee dominant movement that is more challenging than our standard reverse lunges.

name: Squat to Press
descriptionHow: Facing Tonal, take a handle in each hand, placing your feet hip width apart and lined up with the end of the arms.  Bring the handles just outside the shoulders, then lower down into a squat, by moving through your hips like you're sitting back into a chair. Stand by squeezing your glutes,  while simultaneously pushing the handles over your head like you're trying to punch the ceiling. Bring the handles back down to your shoulders in a controlled movement and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This very functional full-body movement helps gain both upper and lower body strength by working the quadriceps, glutes, and shoulders. Squat to press also helps improve coordination, muscular endurance and balance.

name: Barbell Squat to Press
descriptionHow: Facing tonal, stand with feet hip width apart at the end of the arms. Take the bar with hands shoulder width apart. Keeping the bar shoulder height, move through your hips as your knees bend like you’re sitting back into a chair. Squeeze your glutes and push the floor away to come to standing as you press the bar overhead. Once in a standing position, bring the bar back to the shoulder height and repeat.
descriptionWhy: Challenging progression from the original handle version of this compound movement.

name: Iso Squat Hold
descriptionHow: Stand facing away about a foot in front of the wall with feet shoulder width apart. Bring your arms straight overhead. Move through your hips like you’re sitting into a chair, reaching your hips to the wall behind you with thighs parallel to the floor. Hold here.
descriptionWhy: An Iso Squat Hold is a variation of a squat with an isometric emphasis. Since isometric work is excellent for building up the weakest part of a movement, this exercise can significantly improve your squat form.

name: Goblet Split Squat
descriptionHow: Hold the handle at the strap with thumbs wrapped around the top, place it in front of the chest and position yourself in a split stance over your mat, feet about hip width apart. Drop your back knee to the mat, creating 90 degree angles with the knees. Press your front heel down like it's glued to the floor and power up. Bend the knees to drop down to the mat, allowing the back knee to graze the floor, and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: Developing single leg strength is the most efficient way to build overall leg strength and hip stability.

name: Split Squat
descriptionHow: Line your arms up with the end of Tonal’s arms. Take a handle in each hand and get into a half kneeling position with your back knee on the mat, back toes tucked, and front knee directly over the front ankle. Push the floor away from you to stand tall, keeping the feet in the same position. Think elevator with your torso as you power up and lower down until your knee barely touches the mat.
descriptionWhy: The Split Squat is a great exercise to improve the performance of your squats. This unilateral exercise tests your stability and strengthens your bilateral squatting exercises like the Goblet Squat.

name: Goblet Squat
descriptionHow: Hold the handle strap with your thumbs wrapped around the top and position it in front of your chest. Stand with feet shoulder width apart and toes slightly turned out. Reach your hips down and back like you’re sitting into a chair behind you. Push the floor away from you and stand tall powering the hips toward Tonal and repeat.
descriptionWhy: Most people forget how to squat the second they start sitting. Goblet Squats are a great way to reprogram this inborn movement pattern that hides in the recesses of our brains.

name: Bulgarian Split Squat
descriptionHow: Place one foot between Tonal’s arms and reach your opposite leg back, placing the top of the foot on the bench. Hold the handles and stand tall. Keeping your front heel down like it's glued to the floor, bend both knees to drop your hips down until your front thigh is parallel with the floor. Press the floor away from you to stand and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: The Bulgarian Split Squat will fire up your glutes and test balance. This exercise is a progression of the Split Squat and an excellent way to strengthen the Front Squat and Goblet Squat.

name: Bodyweight Squat
descriptionHow: Keeping your chest open to Tonal, reach your hips back like you’re sitting into a chair. Press the floor away from you and squeeze your glutes to power the hips forward toward Tonal and stand tall.
descriptionWhy: Bodyweight Squats are an easy way to get your squats in for the day without loading your skeleton up. They can also be an efficient way to get an "after burn" on heavy leg days.

name: Iso Split Squat
descriptionHow: Get into a half kneeling position with your back knee on your mat, back toes tucked, and front leg planted on the floor in front of you. Lift the back knee just barely above the floor to create 90 degree angles with both knees and raise your arms straight overhead.
descriptionWhy: Isometric holds strengthen a specific portion of your range of motion. If you're looking to build the bottom of your squat or improve your position before you load up on weight, this is a great starting point.

name: Bodyweight Bulgarian Split Squat
descriptionHow: Stand a couple of feet from the bench, facing away. Reach one leg back, placing the top of your foot on the bench. Keeping your front heel down like it's glued to the floor, bend both knees to lower your hips until your front thigh is parallel with the floor. Press the floor away from you to stand and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: The Bodyweight Bulgarian Split Squat fires up the glutes and tests balance. This movement is a progression of the Bodyweight Split Squat and a great way to practice the Bulgarian Split Squat on Tonal.

name: Bodyweight Split Squat
descriptionHow: Lower your back knee to the mat creating 90 degree angles with both knees. Keeping your front heel down like it’s glued to the floor, push the floor away from you to power yourself up and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: Split Squats are the first move to learn on the way to Single Leg Squats. That doesn't mean they're easy; it just means building single leg strength takes a little more time.

name: Assisted Squat
descriptionHow: With arms straight, grip each side of Tonal. Reach your hips back like you're sitting into a chair behind you. Press the floor away from you and squeeze the glutes to stand tall.
descriptionWhy: This is a supported variation of a Bodyweight Squat. It’s an excellent way to perfect your form, squat depth, and muscle engagement.

name: Single Arm Squat w/ Row
descriptionHow: With your arm extended, squat down like you’re sitting back into a chair. As you stand, pull the handle toward your torso using your back and rotating the palm to face your ribcage. Extend the arm as you lower back down to squat and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This will work your posterior chain by challenging your legs, back, and core. It’s a great full-body variation of the squat that encourages strong, upright form.

name: Jump Squat
descriptionHow: Squat down like you're sitting into a chair behind you with your arms straight down toward your hips. Press the floor away from you through your heels to jump up while bringing your arms overhead. Land back in a squat position and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This is a variation of a squat that adds a cardio challenge. Take your squats up a notch by adding a jump and get your heart pumping and legs burning.

name: Squat Jack
descriptionHow: Staying light on your feet, jump out into a wide squat position and quickly back in like you’re playing hopscotch. Keep your knees bent and your torso upright.
descriptionWhy: This squat variation will take up your heart rate while burning out your legs. Add this into your workout as your cardio kick for the day.

name: Racked Squat to Bench
descriptionHow: Facing Tonal, take a handle in each hand and bring them to your shoulders with palms facing each other. Stand with feet hip width apart at the end of Tonal’s arms. Move through your hips, as if someone is pulling you from behind, to tap your glutes on the bench. Stand by squeezing your glutes and pushing the floor away from you.
descriptionWhy: The racked position is easier to handle and control than the goblet, plus it’s similar to the front squat without having to hold the barbell on the shoulders. Adding the bench makes it much more beginner friendly, or can be used for a pause.

name: Racked Squat
descriptionHow: Facing Tonal, take a handle in each hand and bring them to your shoulders with palms facing each other. Stand with feet hip width apart at the end of Tonal’s arms. Move through your hips as your knees bend like you’re sitting back into a chair. Stand by squeezing your glutes and pushing the floor away from you.
descriptionWhy: The racked position is easier to handle and control than the goblet, plus it’s similar to the front squat without having to hold the barbell on the shoulders.

name: Racked Offset Squat
descriptionHow: Facing Tonal, take a handle in one hand and bring it to your shoulder with palms facing in. Stand with feet hip width apart at the end of Tonal’s arms. Move through your hips as your knees bend like you’re sitting back into a chair. Stand by squeezing your glutes and pushing the floor away from you.
descriptionWhy: Similar benefits of weight placement to the racked squat, but an increased need to counter the weight on one side. Very core intensive as anti-lateral flexion.

name: Goblet Squat to Bench
descriptionHow: Hold the handle strap with your thumbs wrapped around the top and place it in front of your chest. Stand over the end of the Tonal arm with feet hip width apart. Move through your hips and bend your knees, as if someone is pulling you from behind, to tap your glutes on the bench. Stand by squeezing your glutes and pushing the floor away from you.
descriptionWhy: A goblet squat movement that encourages good depth and proper mechanics.

name: Racked Offset Split Squat w/ Rotation
shortName: Racked Offset Split Squat w/ rotation
descriptionHow: Facing Tonal, take a handle in one hand and bring it to your shoulder with palm facing in. With your opposite leg forward and feet hip width apart, stand in a split stance position next to the end of Tonal’s arm. As you bend both knees to create 90 degrees, rotate the torso toward the front leg like there’s a magnet on the front knee and opposite elbow. Press through the heel of your front foot to power up to the top position and repeat.
descriptionWhy: Adding some extra complexity to the racked offset split squat. The rotation with take you out of the stable position forcing you to reset your stable core.

name: Mini Sumo Squat
descriptionHow: Sit back and down into your hips as you drive your knees out to keep them in line with your feet and keep your chest up tall. Feet should be slightly wider than shoulder width, toes turned out, and shoulders pulled back. Grab the handle and turn the weight on. With one foot on each side of Tonal's arm, stand by pushing your feet into ground and driving your hips forward as you stand tall.
descriptionWhy: The Mini Sumo Squat is great for those with mobility restrictions who are looking to strengthen their lower body. It puts a lot of focus on the hips and abductors while working on posture and core strength.

name: Bulgarian Split Squat w/ Hip Internal Rotation
shortName: Bulgarian Split Squat w/ Hip IR
descriptionHow: Line one foot up with the end of Tonal’s arms. Reach your opposite leg back, placing the top of your foot on the bench. Grab the handle closest to your front leg with the opposite arm and stand tall. Rotate your torso toward your front leg as you bend your knees to lower your hips until your front thigh is parallel with the floor. Press the floor away from you to come to standing and repeat.
descriptionWhy: Movement designed to encourage a rotation at the bottom of the movement, while still under tension. Encourages you to focus more on maintaining core integrity while under tension. Great move for golfers.

name: Bodyweight Alternating Lateral Squat
descriptionHow: Begin in a wide-legged stance with toes facing forwards. Keeping one leg straight and feet grounded, bend the opposite knee as you drive your hips back and down while keeping a neutral spine and forward gaze. Drive through the floor with the outer edge of your foot to return to the starting position. Continue by bending into the opposite leg, and alternating sides for the remainder of the set.
descriptionWhy: This move improves hip and groin mobility while activating the glutes. This prepares the lower body for compound strength or athletic multi-directional movements like skater bounds.

name: Pistol Squat to Bench
descriptionHow: Start standing with the bench positioned a half step behind you. Shift your weight to one side and raise the opposite foot off the ground. Keeping your raised leg off the ground, lower into a squat, drawing your glutes toward the bench as though sitting into a chair. Drive through your planted foot to return to a tall single-leg stance, returning to the starting position.
descriptionWhy: A modification to the pistol squat that allows you to build single-leg and core strength, and motor control. Isolating one leg at a time will directly improve all variations of lower body strength and power.

name: Bodyweight Squat to Bench w/ Calf Raise
shortName: Bodyweight Squat to Bench w/ Calf Raise
descriptionHow: Begin standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly outward, and the bench positioned a half step behind you. Keeping your chest proud and gaze forward, sit your hips back and down, tapping your glutes to the bench. Drive your heels into the floor, firing your glutes and bracing your core to stand tall. As you reach the top of the squat, continue your ascent by pressing further through the balls of your feet to elevate your heels from the ground.
descriptionWhy: This move improves depth and controlled squatting technique, which prepares you for loaded squat movements. Deep squatting strengthens glute and hamstring muscles, and preserves balanced lower body strength and resilience in training.

name: Bodyweight Squat to Calf Raise
descriptionHow: Begin standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, and toes angled slightly outward. Keeping your chest proud and gaze forward, drive your hips back and down under control until either your thighs are parallel with the floor or you're no longer able to keep a stable, neutral spine. Drive your heels into the floor, firing your glutes and bracing your core to stand tall. As you reach the top of the squat, continue your ascent by pressing further through the balls of your feet to elevate your heels from the ground.
descriptionWhy: This movement develops control through the squat pattern, and is an excellent precursor to explosive plyometric moves like the jump squat, but with a reduced impact on landing.

name: Squat w/ Row
descriptionHow: With arms extended, squat down like you’re sitting back into a chair. Stand up, and pull the rope toward your torso using your back. Extend your arms at the top and then drop back down.
descriptionWhy: This will work your posterior chain by challenging the legs and the upper body. It’s a great full-body variation of a squat.

name: Low Squat Walk Out
descriptionHow: Take the rope in both hands, with your pinkies touching the end of the rope, and get into the bottom of a squat with arms extended out in front of you. Staying in the bottom of your squat, take 6 to 8 steps back away from Tonal. Keep your torso tall and proud. Continuing to stay low, take 6-8 steps forward and repeat.
descriptionWhy: A challenging glute/quad focused movement that encourages a stable lumbar spine and balance to counter the weight.

name: Barbell Front Squat
descriptionHow: Place the barbell on top of the shoulders until it is just barely touching the front of the neck. Cross your arms and lift the elbows to keep the bar in place. Stand with feet shoulder width apart, toes slightly turned out. Reach the hips back and down like you’re into a chair behind you. Press the floor away from you by squeezing your glutes, powering your hips toward Tonal and standing tall.
descriptionWhy: Don't like to Back Squat because you feel like you're always falling forward? Do some Front Squats. Having the weight out in front allows you to sit in a more natural position. These will challenge your core musculature.

name: Barbell Front Racked Split Squat
descriptionHow: Place the barbell on top of the shoulders until it is just barely touching the front of the neck. Cross your arms to hold the bar. Position yourself in a split stance, feet about hip width apart, and lower your back knee toward the floor by bending both knees to a 90 degree angle. Press through the heel of your front foot to power up to the top position and repeat.
descriptionWhy: A quad dominant movement that is more advanced than our other split squats that use the handles.

name: Floor Slide
descriptionHow: Lie face up on your mat with feet planted and knees toward the ceiling. Rest your arms on the floor in a goal post position. With palms facing up, extend the elbows to straighten the arms overhead like you’re reaching to touch something above your head. Once the arms are straight, bring them back to a goal post position.
descriptionWhy: Shoulder mobility is vital for strength performance. Floor slides help increase the flexibility of the shoulder girdle by working through a healthy range of motion.

name: Reach and Rotate Closer
descriptionHow: Get into a tall kneeling position on your mat and then sit back on your heels. Place the roller to one side of your upper body. Extend the arm next to the roller out on the floor and reach the other arm underneath your chest, resting the top of the arm on the roller. Twist slightly at the torso as you roll the top of the arm away from your body, stretching the back of your shoulder.
descriptionWhy: The health of the shoulders dictates how well your upper body can handle a load. Stretching the back and shoulders can allow for a more healthy range of motion and promote strength.

name: Reach and Rotate Opener
descriptionHow: Get into a tall kneeling position on your mat and then sit back on your heels. Bring one hand out in front of you on the floor and the other just behind your ear, bending at the elbow. Rotate at the torso like you’re wringing out a towel, opening your body to the same side as your raised arm. Come back to face the floor and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This stretch helps mobilize the upper thoracic spine and shoulders. The mobility of the thoracic spine is vital for all healthy movement.

name: Prone Shoulder Sweep
descriptionHow: Get into a tall kneeling position seated on your heels, with hands on the floor in front of you. Take one arm and reach it ahead of you, palm facing the floor. Keeping your arm straight, try to touch the walls around you as you sweep the arm out to the side and then behind you. Slowly rotate at the shoulder to face your palm up to the ceiling as you bend your elbow and then rest your hand on your low back. Reverse the movement and repeat. Repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This movement mobilizes the shoulder and upper back. It also helps move the scapula in a range of motion that promotes back and shoulder health.

name: 90-90 Arm Sweep
descriptionHow: Lie on one side of your body with your bottom leg extended on the floor and your upper leg bent at ninety degrees resting on the foam roller. Placing your bottom arm on the floor, extend it out in front of you. Start with your top arm resting on your bottom arm, then sweep it across the floor and over your head to the other side of your body, rotating at the torso. Sweep the arm back over the head and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This is an active recovery movement that promotes a healthy range of motion for the shoulders. It helps create mobility and stability for the rotator cuff while encouraging a healthy and supported spinal position.

name: Scapular Pushup
descriptionHow: With arms straight, slowly drop your chest toward the floor, bringing the shoulder blades together like there are magnets attached to them. Push the floor away from you and use your chest to pull the shoulder blades apart.
descriptionWhy: The Scapular Push Up strengthens the muscles responsible for scapular retraction and protraction. This exercise is great for improving shoulder stability, mobility, and upper body pushing and pulling.

name: Cat-Cow
descriptionHow: Start on all fours on your mat, knees under your hips and wrists under your shoulders, toes tucked. Inhale and open your chest, dropping the navel toward the floor and arching your back. Exhale and pull the navel toward the ceiling, pushing the floor away from you and pulling the shoulder blades apart as you tuck the hips.
descriptionWhy: The Cat-Cow works, mobilizes, and stretches the back. Improve your performance with this functional exercise.

name: Standing Shoulder CARs
descriptionHow: Stand tall with both arms extended in front of your shoulders, fist clenched and thumbs up. Initiate the movement by raising one arm straight up until the bicep is next to the ear. Internally rotate the arm, turning the thumb towards the midline and begin to sweep the arm down and behind you with control. Continue the circular motion until the hand is in line with the hip, at which point the thumb should be facing forward. Drive the arm back to starting position. Do the same on the opposite arm before reversing the range of motion. To reverse, drive one arm down towards the hip, externally rotate the arm to point the thumb outwards and back and begin sweeping the arm up in a circular fashion. When the bicep comes in line with the ear the thumb should be pointing behind you, then lower to starting position. Continue alternating arms and directions for the duration of the set.
descriptionWhy: This controlled articular rotation (CAR) extends range of motion and joint spacing within the shoulder. CARs are a great precursor for upper body pressing movements.

name: Bench Press
descriptionHow: Lie on your back with your head near Tonal. Plant your feet on the floor, chest in line with the end of Tonal’s arms. Grab the handles and bring your arms straight over your chest. Lower down by bending the elbows about 45 degrees from the body with forearm perpendicular to the floor. Press your knuckles straight up to the ceiling to finish with your hands above your chest.
descriptionWhy: Strengthen your chest with the classic Bench Press. This go-to chest exercise works not only the chest but the shoulders and triceps too.

name: Alternating Bench Press
descriptionHow: Lie on your back with your head near Tonal. Plant your feet on the floor and position your chest in line with the end of Tonal’s arms. Grab the handles and bring your arms straight over your chest. Drop one arm down, bending at the elbow in a 45 degree angle from your body with forearm perpendicular with the floor. Press the knuckles straight up to the ceiling to finish with your hands above your chest and alternate sides.
descriptionWhy: The Alternating Bench Press is the same thing as a Bench Press, except you alternate your hands one at a time to increase the amount of tension across your chest and triceps.

name: Single Arm Bench Press
descriptionHow: Lie on your back with your head near Tonal. Plant your feet and align your chest with the end of Tonal’s arms. Grab one handle and bring both arms straight over your chest. Lower down by bending the elbow about 45 degrees from the body, keeping the forearm perpendicular with the floor. Using the chest, press the knuckles straight up to the ceiling and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This movement is a variation of a Bench Press, so the technique is the same. The only difference is that now you're dealing with one arm at a time. This stimulates your core musculature differently and requires more control to perform.

name: Barbell Bench Press
descriptionHow: Position yourself on the bench underneath the barbell with your head near Tonal. Plant your feet on the floor, chest in line with the end of Tonal’s arms. Take the barbell slightly wider than shoulder width and bring your arms straight over your chest. Lower down by bending the elbows about 45 degrees from the body, forearm perpendicular with the floor. Press your knuckles straight up to the ceiling to finish with your hands above your chest.
descriptionWhy: The Barbell Bench Press is a traditional upper body exercise for the chest. It differs from the classic Bench Press because it requires a pronated grip, which alters the shoulder's stability and makes the barbell variation slightly more challenging to execute.

name: Close Grip Barbell Bench Press
descriptionHow: Position yourself on the bench underneath the bar with your head near Tonal. Plant your feet on the floor, chest in line with the end of Tonal's arms. Grasp the bar at shoulder width and extend your arms above your chest. Aim your elbows toward your heels as you lower the bar to your upper rib-cage in a controlled manner, then press your knuckles to the ceiling as you return to the starting position.
descriptionWhy: This variation of the classic bench press puts the focus primarily on the triceps, while still strengthening the chest and front of the shoulders.

name: Wide Grip Barbell Bench Press
descriptionHow: Position yourself on the bench underneath the bar with your head near Tonal. Plant your feet on the floor, chest in line with the end of Tonal's arms. Grasp the bar wider than your shoulders and extend your arms above your chest. Bend your elbows as you lower the bar down to your chest in a controlled manner, then press your knuckles to the ceiling as you return to the starting position.
descriptionWhy: This variation of the classic bench press, recruits the pec muscles twice as much as the triceps compared to the standard grip version. NOTE: Because this movement puts more weight on the shoulder joint, this variation should be avoided if you have pre-existing issues there.

name: Burp
descriptionHow: Power up, reaching your arms overhead and landing with bent knees in a squat. Place your hands on the floor in front of your feet and jump into a plank. Press up and then jump your legs back toward your hands to land in a squat. Power back up reaching your hands to the ceiling and repeat.
descriptionWhy: The Burp is an aerobic and explosive exercise great for building power and endurance. It utilizes every muscle group but, in comparison to the Burpee, it emphasizes endurance and stability.

name: Burpee
descriptionHow: Power up, reaching your arms overhead and landing with bent knees in a squat. Place your hands on the floor in front of your feet and jump into a plank. From the plank lower into a push up. Press up and then jump your legs back toward your hands to land in a squat. Power back up reaching your hands to the ceiling and repeat.
descriptionWhy: If pushups are just too easy, Burpees are for you. They're tough, so make sure you pace yourself.

name: Single Leg Standing Chest Press
descriptionHow: In a single leg standing position with your outside knee up, place your inside arm just outside your shoulder and elbow at your side.  Press the handle forward straightening your arm in front of your chest. Bending at your elbows, bring the weight back toward your shoulders.
descriptionWhy: This variation on the Single Arm Chest Press challenges you to resist rotation in your upper body. This is a great move for lower body strength and core stability.

name: Inline Chest Press
descriptionHow: Facing away from Tonal, get into a half kneeling position with one knee on the mat and the other leg planted in front of you. Position yourself slightly to the side of Tonal’s arm so that it's on the same side as your back leg. Grab the handle with the hand on that side, and extend it in front of your chest. Scoot your front foot in until it's inline with the back knee. Bring the arm back by bending the elbow with the forearm about 45 degrees from the ribcage and parallel with the floor. Press your knuckles straight forward to finish with your hands in front of your chest and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: A variation on the Single Arm Chest Press, this move challenges your ability to resist rotation through your upper body. It’s great for core stability.

name: Tall Kneeling Single Arm Chest Press
shortName: Tall Kn. Single Arm Chest Press
descriptionHow: Facing away from Tonal and slightly to the side of Tonal's arm, get into a tall kneeling position with toes tucked on the floor. Take the handle with your inside hand and start with your arm extended in front of your chest. Bend at the elbow to bring the handle toward you, right under your chest. Using your chest, press the handle forward, straightening your arm to try and punch the wall in front of you.
descriptionWhy: A variation on the Single Arm Chest Press, this move challenges your ability to resist rotation through your upper body from a tall kneeling position. It's great for core stability.

name: Iso Split Squat Single Arm Chest Press
shortName: Iso Split Squat Single Arm Chest Press
descriptionHow: Facing away from Tonal, get into a half kneeling position with one knee on the mat and the other leg planted in front of you. Position yourself slightly to the side of Tonal’s arm so the arm is on the same side as your back leg. Take the handle on the same side and extend it in front of your chest. Lift the back knee just above the mat. Bring the arm back by bending the elbow, with the forearm about 45 degrees from the ribcage and parallel with the floor. Press your knuckles straight forward to finish with your hands in front of your chest and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This move challenges your ability to resist rotation through your upper body from an isometric split squat stance. It’s great for core stability and isometric leg strength.

name: Standing Incline Press
descriptionHow: Press your hands forward and up in front of your forehead using your chest and shoulders. Imagine a barbell lying against your back, from the heel to the top of your head, keeping your body in a straight line. Bend your elbows to bring your hands back to your chest.
descriptionWhy: Strengthen your chest and shoulders with the Standing Incline Press.

name: Standing Decline Chest Press
descriptionHow: Facing away from Tonal, grab a handle in each hand and take a large step forward into a split-stance position, arms straight out just below the chest. Bend your elbows back, aiming for the top of tonal, then fully extend your arms at a 45-degree angle, palms facing down, squeezing the chest. Then repeat.
descriptionWhy: This chest strengthening exercise specifically targets the lower area of the pec called the sternal head. In addition, it also recruits the triceps and the anterior deltoids (front of the shoulder). Because you're standing, this movement forces you to engage your core, which is great for building balance and coordination.

name: Standing Chest Press
descriptionHow: Stand between the arms at shoulder-height position, facing away from Tonal.  Grasp the handles and step forward into a staggered stance.  Press forward until your arms are straight. From there bring your arms back until the handles are at the sides of your chest (a great cue for this is to imagine tucking your shoulders into your back pockets),  and then reverse the motion squeezing your chest and pushing your arms back to the starting position.  NOTE: Never allow your shoulders to rotate forward through the range of motion.
descriptionWhy: This strength building exercise for the chest, shoulders, and triceps, is also great for building balance and coordination since it forces you to engage your core.

name: Single Arm Rotational Punch
descriptionHow: Stand facing away from Tonal in a wide stance and knees soft. Take a handle in one hand and bring it to your chest with your elbow bent and your resting arm in the same position. Rotate at your torso and push across your body, keeping your arm parallel to the floor, while the resting arm swings up and back toward Tonal. Rotate back to face forward as you bring the arms back to the starting position and repeat.
descriptionWhy: Increasing rotational power through the torso and stability through the shoulder girdle. Great for golfers.

name: Beast Pushup
descriptionHow: Starting in a plank position, press into your hands to send your hips back towards your heels, achieving a deep bend in the knees with shins parallel to the ground. Actively drive through your forefoot to return into plank position. Lower your chest in line with your elbows for a pushup, keeping elbows at a 45-degree angle from the armpit and core engaged to keep the body in a straight line from heel to head.
descriptionWhy: A dynamic pushup variation that improves shoulder mobility and stability, core strength, and activates the hip and quad muscles.

name: Lateral Raise
descriptionHow: Take a handle in each hand and stand facing away from Tonal. With soft elbows, lift your arms up to your sides toward the ceiling until they reach shoulder height. Lower the arms with control and repeat.
descriptionWhy: Big shoulders don’t build themselves. This is a classic bodybuilding movement used to isolate your deltoids.

name: Triceps Kickback
descriptionHow: Keeping your elbows bent, bring them to your sides. Extend your elbows, bringing the handles back toward your hips like you’re trying to touch the wall behind you, working the back of your arms. Bend your elbows to a 90 degree angle to return to start.
descriptionWhy: The Tricep Kickback is a great way to add isometric strength to your back. It’s also an effective way to increase your tricep strength.

name: Biceps Curl
descriptionHow: Holding the handles, stand tall with arms extended by your hips. Flex the elbows to bring your palms toward your armpits like you’re cracking a walnut between your forearm and bicep. Extend the elbows to bring your hands back to your hips and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This is the classic bodybuilding Bicep Curl that will really shape those biceps into eye-popping peaks and valleys.

name: Front Raise
descriptionHow: Facing away from Tonal, grab the handles and take a stable base position. Using your shoulders and upper back, raise your arms straight in front of you until they’re parallel with the floor. With control, lower your arms back down to your sides and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This exercise is a great way to challenge the deltoids by incorporating a longer lever arm. To burn out and build strong shoulders, add these in as a finish to your upper body workouts.

name: Seated Biceps Curl
descriptionHow: Flex the elbows to bring your palms toward your armpits like you’re trying to crack a walnut in the crease of your elbow. Extend the elbows to bring your hands back to your hips and repeat.
descriptionWhy: The Seated Bicep Curl creates a stable environment for strengthening the biceps. Bicep strength is essential in big exercises like the Seated Row and the Chin Up.

name: Lying Biceps Curl
descriptionHow: Pretending your upper arms are glued to the floor so they can’t lift, pull the handles toward your shoulders, flexing at the elbows. Slowly lower back to start and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This is a supported variation of a Bicep Curl that helps isolate the bicep. Use this exercise to perfect your form for Bicep Curls or to do isolation bicep work.

name: Skull Crusher
descriptionHow: Lie on your back with your head near Tonal. Plant your feet on the floor, chest in line with the end of Tonal's arms. Grab the handles and bring your arms straight over your chest. With palms facing forward, lower your hands toward your forehead by bending the elbows, as if your knuckles could crush your skull. Press your knuckles straight up to the ceiling to finish with your hands above your chest.
descriptionWhy: Tricep strength is vital for movements like the Bench Press. This move will work your triceps and test your shoulder stability.

name: Decline Chest Fly
descriptionHow: Take a handle in each hand and extend the arms in front of you slightly below your chest like you’re hugging a beach ball. Open your arms back and up toward Tonal, keeping them slightly bent, until they are almost in line with your shoulders. Bring your arms back to center and slightly below the chest, and repeat.
descriptionWhy: The Decline Chest Fly increases the strength and size of the lower pec muscles.

name: Middle Chest Fly
descriptionHow: Start with arms extended in front of your chest with elbows softly bent like you’re hugging a beach ball. Open your arms toward Tonal until they are inline with the chest. Keeping the arms in the same position, bring them back to start and repeat.
descriptionWhy: The Middle Chest Fly is a great complement to the bench press. It increases the strength and size of the pec muscles.

name: Incline Chest Fly
descriptionHow: Take a handle in each hand and stand facing away from Tonal in a split stance with arms at your sides and palms facing forward. Keeping a soft elbow bend, bring your arms forward and up toward your chin like you’re trying to scoop up the air and end with arms in front of your face and palms facing up. Bring your arms back to your sides to finish and repeat.
descriptionWhy: The Incline Chest Fly increases the strength and size of the upper pec muscles.

name: Single Arm Incline Chest Fly
descriptionHow: Take a handle in one hand and stand facing away from Tonal in a split stance. Start with both arms extended in front of you at chin level with palms facing up slightly, one hand without a handle. Keeping a soft elbow bend, bring the arm with the handle back to the outside of your hip, palm facing forward. Use your chest to scoop your arm forward and up, coming back to meet the other hand. Repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This is a more difficult variation of the Decline Fly because it challenges your core while isolating one side of the chest.

name: Single Arm Decline Chest Fly
descriptionHow: Take a handle in one hand and stand facing away from Tonal in a split stance. Start with both arms extended in front of you at navel height, palms facing each other, one hand without a handle. Keeping a soft elbow bend, bring the arm with the handle back and up toward Tonal so your elbow reaches shoulder height. Use your chest to scoop your arm forward and down, coming back to meet the other hand. Repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: A more challenging variation of the Decline Fly, this move isolates one side of your chest while testing your core strength.

name: Reverse Fly
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal. Take the left handle in the right hand, and the right handle in the left hand. Bring your hands in front of your chest with arms slightly bent. Using your back and keeping distance between your shoulders and ears, open your arms back to the wall behind you until the elbows are in line with the shoulders. Bring your arms back to center like you’re hugging a beach ball in front of your chest and repeat.
descriptionWhy: Burn out the back with the Reverse Fly. This single-joint exercise is perfect to light up the middle and upper back muscles.

name: Lying Face Curl
descriptionHow: Take a handle in each hand and lay on the bench with your head toward Tonal. Your face should be positioned underneath the end of the arms. Start with your arms fully extended above your chest, palms facing toward Tonal, then flex your elbows, bringing your hands toward your shoulders. Imagine your are cracking a walnut with your biceps and forearms. Extend your elbows to return to the starting position and repeat.
descriptionWhy: The biceps are two-headed muscles made up of a long and short head. The positioning of this exercise, with your arms perpendicular to the floor, helps emphasize the latter with an intense contraction. This helps develop a stronger mind-muscle connection that carries over and improves other bicep exercises.

name: Alternating Biceps Curl
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal and take a handle in each hand with your arms at your sides. Flex one elbow, bringing your palm toward your armpit, keeping your elbow pointed toward the floor. Imagine you're cracking a walnut with your bicep and forearm. Extend your elbow, bringing your hand back to your hip and switch sides.
descriptionWhy: A primary benefit of this bicep strengthening movement is the ability to fully focus on one arm at time. This exercise also allows for momentary recovery of one bicep while the other one contracts, and because you're standing, it forces your body to engage the stabilizing muscles of the legs and core.

name: Reverse Grip Biceps Curl
descriptionHow: Stand tall and hold the bar in a pronated position (palms facing you), arms extended. Flex the elbows and lift the bar so the back of your hands move toward your armpits. Imagine you're cracking a walnut between your bicep and forearm. Extend the elbows to bring the bar back to your hips.
descriptionWhy: This variation of the bicep curl actually promotes greater muscle activation because of the pronated grip, and can help correct imbalances. Adding this exercise to your routine can help increase your ability to lift heavier weight during standard bicep curls.

name: Bench Chest Fly
descriptionHow: Lie on your back with head near Tonal. Plant your feet on the floor with your head in line with the end of the arms. Grab the handles and bring your arms over your chest with your palms facing each other. With the elbows slightly bent, open your arms wide toward the floor until they're in line with the chest. Come back to the starting position by pretending you're hugging a beach ball, then repeat.
descriptionWhy: This movement is a great way to both strengthen and open the chest. Opening the chest can help reduce upper back pain, increase range of motion, and teach scapular retraction which is ESSENTIAL for correctly doing many upper-body exercises.

name: Internal Shoulder Rotation
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal, grasping one of the handles. Lock one elbow by your side at a ninety-degree angle, with the forearm extended forward. Keeping your elbow locked against your side, pull the cable toward your abs by internally rotating the shoulder. Squeeze for a moment and then return to the starting position.
descriptionWhy: This exercise targets and strengthens the rotator cuff, particularly the subscapularis muscle, as well as the pectoralis, which is critical for shoulder stability.

name: External Shoulder Rotation
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal, grasping one of the handles. Lock one elbow by your side at a ninety-degree angle, with the forearm across your belly. Keeping your elbow locked against your side, pull the cable away from your body by externally rotating the shoulder. Then return to the starting position. TIP: Keep a towel under your elbow and don't let it drop.
descriptionWhy: This exercise targets and strengthens the rotator cuff, particularly the infraspinatus muscle, as well as the posterior deltoid, which is critical for shoulder stability. This an important exercise for balancing the shoulder and avoiding injury!

name: Reverse Grip Triceps Extension
descriptionHow: Grab both handles in a supinated grip (palms facing you), keeping your elbows pressed against your side, wrists straight.  Then squeeze the weight down until your arms are fully extended. Allow your forearms to return to the starting position without moving your elbows.
descriptionWhy: This isolation movement is an effective way to build strength in the triceps, putting particular focus on the medial head which helps stabilize the elbow and gives the arm a more defined, proportional look.

name: Seated Alternating Biceps Curl
descriptionHow: Grab both handles with your palms facing away from you, extend your arms past your hips, and bring one of them toward your armpit, like you're trying to crack a walnut in the crease of your elbow. Then in a controlled manner, extend your elbow back to your hip and repeat with the other side.
descriptionWhy: The seated alternating bicep curl creates a stable way to strengthen the biceps (as well as the surrounding muscles), allowing you to focus on one arm at a time. In addition, this movement aids in shoulder stability, which is critical for overhead exercises.

name: Shoulder Shrug
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal with a handle in each hand. Squeeze your shoulders to your ears, then softly release them to their natural position.
descriptionWhy: This movement helps strengthen the trapezius muscles, which helps maintain proper posture by stabilizing the upper back and neck.

name: Bent Over IYT Raise
descriptionHow: From a standing position, slightly bend your knees and hinge forward at the hips until your chest is at a 45-degree angle from the ground and your arms are hanging in line with your knees. With straight arms, extend your thumbs toward the ceiling, biceps nearing the ears into an "I" position, and then lower. Next, extend arms upward at a 45-degree angle from the shoulders into a "Y" position, and then lower. Lastly, keeping the head and neck neutral, extend the arms laterally, creating a "T" position, then repeat.
descriptionWhy: This movement improves shoulder mobility and strengthens the postural muscles of the hips, upper back, and neck.

name: Triceps Bench Dip
descriptionHow: Start seated on the bench with your hands gripping the side of the bench, fingers wrapped around. Keeping your shoulders stacked over your wrists, walk your feet forward until your legs are fully extended. Drive your palms into the bench and extend your arms to elevate and clear your hips from the end of the bench. Lower your hips and torso with control by bending at the elbows, until your shoulders approach elbow height. Return to the top position by driving your palms into the bench and extending your arms.
descriptionWhy: This move develops tricep strength as well as shoulder mobility and stability. This improves control for all upper-body pressing movements like the bench press and overhead press variations.

name: Hammer Curl
descriptionHow: Holding the rope, stand tall with arms extended in front of your hips. Flex the elbows to bring your hands toward your armpits like you’re cracking a walnut between your forearm and bicep. Extend the elbows to bring your hands down and repeat.
descriptionWhy: Hammer curls will help your biceps and forearms get bigger and stronger. Pair them with a supination curl to shape your biceps.

name: Y-Pull
descriptionHow: With straight arms, lift the rope in front of you to bring your biceps to your ears, aiming your hands toward the wall behind you. Lower back down to start with straight arms.
descriptionWhy: This single-joint exercise is essential for the health of the shoulders and upper back. Work your shoulders and traps and test your posterior chain strength with the Y-Pull.

name: Triceps Extension
descriptionHow: Extend your elbows to bring your hands down toward your hips, working the back of the arms. Imagine a magnet between your shoulder blades as you pull the rope down. Control your hands back up until they are just above the elbows.
descriptionWhy: This movement is a traditional bodybuilding isolation movement.  It's an effective way to build your overhead strength, stretch your triceps/lats, and mold the arms you've been looking for.

name: Overhead Triceps Extension
descriptionHow: Take the rope in both hands and stand 12 inches forward from the end of the arm. Stand in a split stance position facing away from Tonal and bring the rope overhead with arms extended in front of you. Keeping your upper arms next to your ears, bend the elbows to bring your hands behind your head. With control, extend the elbows like you’re throwing something toward the floor.
descriptionWhy: Tricep strength is important for upper body pushing movements like the Bench Press and Overhead Press. The Overhead Tricep Extension strengthens the triceps so you can lift heavier in your big compound exercises.

name: Single Arm Triceps Extension
descriptionHow: Extend the elbow to bring your hand down toward your hip, working the back of the arm and aiming your knuckles to the floor. Control your hand back up until it’s just above the elbow.
descriptionWhy: This is a traditional bodybuilding isolation movement with a twist. It's an effective way to build overhead and core strength and sculpted arms.

name: Barbell Biceps Curl
descriptionHow: Stand tall and hold the bar with arms extended in front of you, palms facing Tonal. Flex the elbows to bring your palms toward your armpits like you’re cracking a walnut between your forearm and bicep. Extend the elbows to bring your hands back to your hips and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This is a classic bicep exercise that requires a supinated grip. It shapes strong biceps that can help with exercises like the Barbell Bent Over Row.

name: Reverse Grip Barbell Biceps Curl
descriptionHow: Stand tall and hold the bar in a pronated position (palms facing you), arms extended. Flex the elbows and lift the bar so the back of your hands move toward your armpits. Imagine you're cracking a walnut between your bicep and forearm. Extend the elbows to bring the bar back to your hips.
descriptionWhy: This variation of the bicep curl actually promotes greater muscle activation because of the pronated grip, and can help correct imbalances. Adding this exercise to your routine can help increase your ability to lift heavier weight during standard bicep curls.

name: Barbell Front Raise
descriptionHow: Facing away from Tonal, grab the barbell with your hands and feet both positioned shoulder width apart. Begin with the bar resting against your thighs, then raise the barbell in a controlled manner to shoulder height. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This exercise is a fantastic way to strengthen and create definition in the front and sides of the shoulders, also known as the anterior and medial (or lateral) deltoids. Targeting these muscles will help improve pressing movements, as well as many everyday activities!

name: Reverse Grip Barbell Triceps Extension
descriptionHow: Grasp the barbell in a supinated grip (palms facing up), keeping your elbows pressed against your sides, wrists straight. Then squeeze the weight down until your arms are fully extended. Allow your forearms to return to the starting position without moving your elbows.
descriptionWhy: This isolation movement is an effective way to build strength in the triceps, putting particular focus on the medial head which helps stabilize the elbow and gives the arm a more defined, proportional look.

name: Barbell Skull Crusher
descriptionHow: Lie on your back with your head near Tonal. Plant your feet on the floor, chest in line with the end of Tonal's arms. Make sure to have a sturdy body position so you're not arching your back. Grab the barbell with a shoulder-width grip, palms facing forward, and extend it straight over your chest with arms perpendicular to the floor. Slowly lower the barbell toward your forehead ONLY by bending the elbows, and then extend it back to the starting position above your chest.
descriptionWhy: Your triceps take up two-thirds of your upper arm and this is an EXCELLENT exercise for strengthening them! This will be a big help with chest and shoulder exercises, such as bench and overhead presses.

name: Seated Overhead Press
descriptionHow: Press your arms up overhead, straightening the elbows, and rotating the palms to face Tonal while keeping the torso upright like you're seated against a wall. Slowly let the weight down and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This overhead press will really challenge your core strength and stability.

name: Standing Overhead Press
descriptionHow: Press both arms up overhead reaching the knuckles toward the ceiling, but keeping the shoulders pulled toward the floor. Bend the elbows to slowly bring the hands back to start.
descriptionWhy: The Standing Overhead Press is among the most challenging exercises for the upper body. Test not only your shoulder strength but also your core stability with this exercise.

name: Half Kneeling Overhead Press
descriptionHow: Get into a half kneeling position with your back knee on the mat at the end of Tonal's arms. Take a handle in each hand and bring them right outside your shoulders with your palms facing each other. Press your arms up overhead, straightening the elbows, rotating the palms to face Tonal while keeping your torso upright like you're seated against a wall. Slowly let the weight down and alternate sides.
descriptionWhy: After mastering the Single Arm Overhead Press, you'll be ready to try this move. Two arms pressing overhead offers more of a challenge.

name: Half Kneeling Alternating Overhead Press
descriptionHow: Get into a half kneeling position with your back knee on your mat at the end of Tonal’s arms. Take a handle in each hand and bring your hands right outside your shoulders with your palms facing each other. Press one arm up overhead, straightening the elbow, and rotating the palm to face Tonal while keeping your torso upright like you’re seated against a wall. Slowly lower the weight and alternate sides.
descriptionWhy: This movement is a catchall for hip and core stability, overhead strength, and mobility.

name: Half Kneeling Single Arm Overhead Press
shortName: Half Kneeling Single Arm Overhead Press
descriptionHow: Get into a half kneeling position with your back knee on the mat at the end of Tonal’s arms. Take a handle in one hand and bring it right outside your shoulder with your palm facing in. Press your arm up overhead, straightening the elbow, and rotating your palm to face Tonal while keeping your torso upright like you’re seated against a wall. Slowly lower the weight down and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This is the first step in understanding how to overhead press. Using only one arm allows the least amount of restriction. The half kneeling position provides an added stability challenge.

name: Seated Alternating Overhead Press
descriptionHow: Press one arm up overhead, straightening the elbow and rotating the palm to face Tonal. Keep your torso upright like you’re seated against a wall. Slowly let the weight down and repeat on the other side, alternating sides.
descriptionWhy: The Seated Alternating Overhead Press is a great exercise to test core stability and shoulder strength.

name: Seated Single Arm Overhead Press
descriptionHow: Press your arm up overhead, straightening the elbow and rotating the palm to face Tonal, while keeping the torso upright like you’re seated against a wall. Slowly let the weight down and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: The Seated Single Arm Overhead Press tests each shoulder's strength individually while also lighting up the core.

name: Half Kneeling Vertical Push-Pull
descriptionHow: Facing away from Tonal, get into a half kneeling position with the leg forward that’s on the same side as the higher arm. Take a handle in each hand with the lower handle at your shoulder and higher arm extended, both palms facing each other. Using your shoulder, press up with the lower arm as you simultaneously pull down using your lat with the opposite arm.
descriptionWhy: Vertical opposing movement that puts a lot of focus on core stability, & CNS patterns through the sagittal plane.

name: Standing Barbell Overhead Press
descriptionHow: Press the bar straight over your head until your arms are fully extended and aim your knuckles to the ceiling. Try to keep your forearms perpendicular to the floor at all times. Bend your elbows to bring the bar to the bottom position.
descriptionWhy: The most traditional but most restrictive version of the overhead press will really challenge your core strength and stability.

name: Barbell Seated Overhead Press
descriptionHow: Sit facing Tonal straddling the bench. Grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder width and bring it in front of your chest at shoulder height, with wrists straight and elbows at your sides. Press the bar straight over your head until your arms are fully extended and aim your knuckles to the ceiling. Try to keep your forearms perpendicular to the floor at all times. Bend your elbows to bring the bar to the bottom position.
descriptionWhy: This is a less challenging variation of the Standing Barbell Overhead Press. Use the bench for stability while strengthening the shoulders and core.

name: Tall Kneeling Single Arm Lat Pulldown
shortName: Tall Kn. Single Arm Lat Pulldown
descriptionHow: Using your back, pull the handle to the outside of your shoulder, rotating your hand to face your body as you pull, and aim your elbow toward your heels. Control the weight back up, straightening at your elbow.
descriptionWhy: This Pull Up alternative includes more core work. Working to stabilize rotation during this movement will give you even more of a core focus.

name: Seated Lat Pulldown
descriptionHow: Using your back, pull the handles to the outside of your shoulders and bend your elbows like there are magnets on your elbows and ribcage. Slowly control the weight back to start and repeat.
descriptionWhy: The seated version of the Lat Pulldown isolates your pulling muscles and really overloads your body for some fast gains.

name: Neutral Lat Pulldown
descriptionHow: Start with arms extended overhead, palms facing Tonal. Drive the elbows down toward the floor and pull the handles to the outside of your shoulders, rotating your hands to face your body. Control the weight back up to starting position, straightening at the elbows.
descriptionWhy: This move isolates all of your pulling muscles and really overloads your body for some fast gains.

name: Alternating Neutral Lat Pulldown
descriptionHow: Start with arms flexed, palms at chest height and facing each other in a neutral grip. Using your back, raise one handle until you arm is fully extended, rotating it to face Tonal. Pull the handle back to the starting position using your back muscles and bend your elbow like there are magnets on your elbow and rib cage. Switch hands and repeat.
descriptionWhy: Lat strength is important to help you maintain good posture and strong shoulders. Lat Pulldowns are an easy way to help you get better at Pull Ups.

name: X-Pulldown w/ Triceps Extension
descriptionHow: Using your back, pull the handles down toward your shoulders, rotating the hands to face your chest as you pull. Extend your elbows, reaching your knuckles toward the floor to work the back of your arms, keeping your palms facing up. Bend your elbows to bring your hands back to your shoulders and then extend your arms back to the starting position.
descriptionWhy: This move gives you the strength benefit of a Pull Up, the movement benefit of a shoulder rotation, and the tricep/core benefit of a Tricep Extension.

name: X-Pulldown
descriptionHow: Using your back, pull the handles down toward your shoulders, rotating them to face your chest as you pull, and aiming your elbows to where the wall meets the floor behind you. Extend your arms back to the starting position with palms facing Tonal.
descriptionWhy: The X-Pulldown is a powerful exercise to work the lats. It's a progression from the Neutral Lat Pulldown due to the added challenge of a scapula rotation.

name: Seated Single Arm Lat Pulldown
descriptionHow: Using your back, pull the handle to the outside of your shoulder and bend your elbow like there are magnets on your elbow and ribcage. Slowly release the weight back up and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This move isolates your pulling muscles on one side, which allows each side to build strength on its own. Because it’s unilateral, it also lights up the core.

name: Straight Arm Pulldown
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal with feet hip distance apart, knees soft and stable. Take a handle in each hand and move 12 inches back. Start with your arms out in front of you with your hands just above your shoulders, elbows slightly bent. Pull the handles down toward your hips, moving from your shoulders and back, squeezing your lats. Then let the handles up with control until your hands are just above your shoulders and repeat. TIP: Do not let the elbows flex or extend throughout the movement.
descriptionWhy: This is an excellent exercise for increasing lat strength and development. In addition, this variation is ideal for people who may have trouble feeling their backs work when doing a traditional lat pulldown.

name: Half Kneeling Single Arm Pulldown (Ipsilateral)
descriptionHow: Take a handle in one hand and get into a half kneeling position with your same side knee forward on your mat. Start with your arm extended overhead, palms facing in. Using your back, pull the handle to the outside of your shoulder and aim your elbow toward your floor. Let the weight back up with control, straightening at your elbow.
descriptionWhy: Great progression of the half kneeling pull down with ability to place a greater emphasis on power.

name: Half Kneeling Single Arm Pulldown (Contralateral)
descriptionHow: Take a handle in one hand and get into a half kneeling position with your opposite knee forward on your mat. Start with your arm extended overhead, palms facing in. Using your back, pull the handle to the outside of your shoulder and aim your elbow toward your floor. Let the weight back up with control, straightening at your elbow.
descriptionWhy: A single arm pulldown using the opposite side arm as the front/flexed hip side. This variation allows for diversity in torso stability and a greater emphasis on anti-lateral flexion of the core.

name: Neutral Single Arm Straight Arm Pulldown
shortName: Neutral Single Arm Straight Arm Pulldown
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal with your feet hip distance apart and knees soft. Grab the rope in one hand and take a step backward. Start with your arm straight out in front of you, your hand slightly higher than your shoulder, elbow slightly bent. Pull the rope down toward the hip moving from the shoulder and back, squeezing the lat at the bottom. Then let your hand up with control until it is just above your shoulder and repeat. TIP: Do not let the elbow flex or extend throughout the movement.
descriptionWhy: This is an excellent exercise for increasing lat strength and development. Moving one arm at a time allows you to focus on each side contracting, increasing that mind-muscle connection. In addition, this variation is ideal for people who may have trouble feeling their back work when doing a traditional lat pulldown.

name: Barbell Chinup
descriptionHow: Grip the bar shoulder width apart with palms facing your body. Get into a tall kneeling position with toes tucked on the floor. Using your back, pull the bar toward your collar bones by bending your elbows and drawing them down and back away from Tonal. Control the weight back up, straightening at the elbows, and repeat.
descriptionWhy: The Barbell Chin Up is a classic exercise that works the lats and biceps. The supinated grip emphasizes the biceps' effort while still working the lats for a strong back and arms!

name: Barbell Seated Lat Pulldown
descriptionHow: Facing Tonal, sit straddling the bench slightly behind the end of the arms and grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder width. Using your back, pull the bar toward your collar bones by bending your elbows and drawing them down like there are magnets on your elbow and rib cage. Let the weight back up with control, straightening at the elbows and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This big pulling exercise is great for building strong lats. It will help you gain size and strength quickly.

name: Barbell Straight Arm Pulldown
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal with feet hip distance apart, knees soft. Take the bar and move a step back. Start with the bar out in front of you, positioned slightly higher than your shoulders, elbows softly bent. Pull the bar down toward your hips moving from the shoulders and back, squeezing your lats at the bottom. Then let the bar up with control until your hands are just above your shoulders and repeat. TIP: Do not let the elbows flex or extend throughout the movement.
descriptionWhy: This is an excellent exercise for increasing lat strength and development. In addition, this variation is ideal for people who may have trouble feeling their backs work when doing a traditional lat pulldown.

name: Barbell Pullover
descriptionHow: Facing away from Tonal, step behind the bar and hold it shoulder width apart. Walk forward to the bench and lay on your back with your head toward Tonal. Bring your arms straight over your chest. With a slight bend in the elbows, lower the bar down and back toward the floor until the bar is just past your head. Using your lats, triceps and chest lift the bar back up until the bar is over your chest.
descriptionWhy: A staple across the lifting community, big focus on lat activation.

name: Incline Pushup
descriptionHow: Place your hands at the edge of the bench slightly wider than the shoulders, with legs extended behind you on the floor. Bend the elbows about 45 degrees from your body as you aim your chest to your fingertips. Once your chest is just above the bench, press through your hands to push back up.
descriptionWhy: If your strength isn’t developed enough to do a full Push Up, start here.

name: Pushup
descriptionHow: Bending the elbows about 45 degrees from the torso, drop your chest toward the floor aiming for your fingertips. Once at the bottom, push the floor away from you while pressing with your chest.
descriptionWhy: This exercise is an effective way to build upper body endurance and strength. Basically, everyone who's strength training still uses this classic exercise.

name: Foot Elevated Pushup
descriptionHow: Place your hands on the floor a few feet away from the bench, slightly wider than your shoulders. Position both feet on the bench with toes tucked. Bend at your elbows and keep your upper arm about 45 degrees from your torso as you drop down and aim your collar bones to the floor. Once at the bottom, push the floor away from you, pressing with your chest and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This alternative to a traditional Pushup is for someone who is just too good at a standard Pushup and is looking for a little bit extra.

name: Kneeling Pushup
descriptionHow: Start in a modified plank position with your hands planted under the shoulders and your knees on the ground. Extend through your hips to create a straight line from your knees to your shoulders by shifting weight into your hands. Lower your body into a pushup, with your chest in line with your thumbs while driving your elbows back at a 45-degree angle from your torso. Press your palms through the ground, extending your arms to return to starting position.
descriptionWhy: This pushup variation builds upper body and core strength and stability, while minimizing strain on wrists and shoulders as you progress into more complex and challenging movements.

name: Traveling Pushup
descriptionHow: From a high-plank position, walk one hand under the center of your chest, then step the other hand outward to land shoulder-width distance apart. Lower your body toward the floor in a straight line until your elbows approach a 90-degree bend, then push through the ground to return to the top position, arms fully extended. In the opposite direction, step your hand inward to land under your chest, then step the other hand away to land at shoulder width. Lower your body toward the ground, press back to top position, and continue with reps, switching direction after each pushup for the duration of the set.
descriptionWhy: In addition to building upper-body strength and shoulder stability as in the traditional pushup, this variation adds dynamic shoulder and torso stabilizing strength which translates to a greater range of upper-body movements on Tonal.

name: Alternating Staggered Pushup
descriptionHow: From a high-plank position, step one hand slightly forward and the other slightly back before lowering your chest, torso, and hips in line with the thumbs for a pushup. Press your palms through the ground to elevate your torso to the starting position. Alternate forward and back hand positions, and repeat pushup reps for the duration of the set.
descriptionWhy: This advanced pushup builds chest, tricep, and shoulder strength and dynamic stability by incorporating movement variability to a classic exercise.

name: Bent Over Row
descriptionHow: Grab the handles and take a small step back. Position yourself in an athletic stance facing Tonal with feet hip width apart. Hinge at the hips into a bent over position. Start with your palms facing the floor and pull the handles toward your ribcage using your back, rotating the palms to face each other. Aim your elbows to where the ceiling meets the wall as you pull. Keep control of the weight using your back as you lower the handles and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This classic movement is great for maintaining postural integrity. It also builds back and bicep pulling strength.

name: Half Kneeling Single Arm Row
descriptionHow: Using your back, pull the handle toward your ribcage with your palm facing your body, aiming your elbow to the wall behind you. Extend your elbow to straighten your arm and return to starting position, then repeat.
descriptionWhy: This movement hits your back and core.

name: Seated Row
descriptionHow: Using your back, drive your elbows like you're trying to touch the wall behind you and pull the handles to your torso, palms facing your ribcage. Release the weight forward again with control, rotating the palms to face the floor, and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This is a supported upper body pulling exercise. It works the back and biceps in a stable environment to encourage pulling more weight.

name: Single Arm Bent Over Row
descriptionHow: Grab the handle with one hand. On the same side, plant your leg firmly on the floor with a soft knee. Place your opposite limbs on the bench, hand under your shoulder and knee under your hip. Using your back, imagine your shoulder blades are sliding down to your hips and pull the handle toward your torso with your palm facing your body. Release the weight forward again with control, and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This is a classic movement for building back muscle. It will teach you how to move a heavy object safely and effectively.

name: Standing Single Arm Row
descriptionHow: Using your back, pull the handle toward your torso with your palm facing your body, aiming your elbow to the wall behind you. Extend your elbow and straighten your arm back to the starting position. Repeat.
descriptionWhy: Use the Standing Single Arm Row to isolate each side of the back. Resisting rotation in the torso will also work the core.

name: Rotational Row
descriptionHow: Rotate toward Tonal, reaching the handle down toward the end of the arm. Like you're starting a lawn mower, pull the handle toward your ribcage, using your back. Rotate the hips to shift your body into the outside leg, bringing the cable across your body. Slowly bring the handle back toward Tonal and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This movement helps connect lower and upper body power in multiple planes of motion. If you’re playing sports, it can benefit your ability to change direction quickly.

name: Standing Alternating Push-Pull
descriptionHow: Get into an athletic stance facing to the side of Tonal between the arms, and take the handle that’s behind you with your outside hand and bring it to your chest. Take the handle that’s in front of you with your other arm. Keep your arm straight. Simultaneously, press the outside handle forward while pulling the inside handle toward your chest. As you push, face the palm to the floor; and as you pull, face the palm to the body. Keep your hips unmoved, but rotate your torso like you’re wringing out a towel.
descriptionWhy: This powerful exercise is great for integrating rotational work. It also strengthens the upper body’s pushing and pulling muscles.

name: Seated Alternating Row
descriptionHow: Facing Tonal, take a handle in each hand. Sit on the floor and slide back, anchoring your feet against the end of the bench. Sitting tall, use your back to pull one handle toward your torso, palm facing your body. Let the handle forward with control and repeat on the other side.
descriptionWhy: A seated supported row using the bench up against a wall to increase power. Alternating reps encourages the non-working hand to grip tightly and maintain core integrity.

name: Upright Row
descriptionHow: Using your shoulders and back, pull the rope toward your chin. Don’t let your elbows go higher than your shoulders. Lower back down to the starting position.
descriptionWhy: Put this movement into your routine for an added shoulder, posture, and upper trap workout.

name: Standing Face Pull
descriptionHow: Using the shoulders and back, pull the rope toward your ears by aiming your elbows wide to the wall behind you. Slowly move your hands forward to finish.
descriptionWhy: You know you're doing this movement right if you're slightly worried that you might hit your forehead with the handles or rope. This is a great way to strengthen your upper back, shoulders, and neck.

name: Barbell Bent Over Row
descriptionHow: Grab the bar with palms facing up, take one small step back from the end of Tonal’s arms and stand tall. Get into a hip hinge position by bending the knees softly and reaching your glutes back to the wall behind you as you hinge your torso forward. Pull the bar to your navel using your back and aim your elbows to where the ceiling meets the wall. Keep control of the weight using your back as you lower the bar and repeat.
descriptionWhy: Upper body pulling exercises are essential for your strength, and the Barbell Bent Over Row is a powerful exercise to help you get stronger. The supinated grip emphasizes the biceps, and the bent-over position tests posterior chain strength.

name: Ankle Strap Move
descriptionHow:
Use this move to create an original movement. Follow these steps to display the power, range of motion, reps, and more:
