Select the weight and get in position. Turn on the weights and perform the movement with your best form. Turn off the weights to finish.
descriptionWhy: These moves allow you to get creative and challenge yourself in new ways. Performing these movements will not impact your strength score.

Select the weight and get in position. Turn on the weights and perform the movement with your best form. Turn off the weights to finish.
descriptionWhy: These moves allow you to get creative and challenge yourself in new ways. Performing these movements will not impact your strength score.

name: Prone Bench Hamstring Curl
descriptionHow: Position the bench just beyond the ends of Tonal's arms. Facing away from Tonal, lie face down with your knees just off the edge of the bench. Use a handle to turn on the weight. With your legs extended and feet flexed, bend your knees to curl both heels in toward your glutes. Lower with control and repeat.
descriptionWhy: This movement isolates the hamstrings to build strength in the back of the legs.

name: Prone Bench Single Leg Hamstring Curl
shortName: Prone Bench Single Leg Hamstring Curl
descriptionHow: Position the bench just beyond the ends of Tonal's arms. Facing away from Tonal, lie face down with your knees just off the edge of the bench. Use a handle to turn on the weight. With your working leg extended and foot flexed, bend your kneel to curl your heel in toward your glute. Lower with control and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: Isolating the hamstrings one side at a time builds unilateral strength.

name: Quadruped Donkey Kick
descriptionHow: Start facing Tonal on hands and knees, with your working leg in line with Tonal's arm and the cable running along the inside of your shin. Straddle Tonal's arm with your hands and keep your shoulders stacked over your wrist. Extend your working leg straight back like you’re stamping the wall behind you without arching your back. Return your knee under your hip and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This movement targets the gluteus maximus through hip extension. It's great for strengthening and building the muscles of the glutes.

name: Standing Diagonal Glute Kickback
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal, with your working leg in line with Tonal's arm. Shift your weight into your standing leg and hold onto Tonal for support. Extend your working leg back and slightly out, aiming your foot toward the corner of the room. Keep your body tall and your hips squared forward. Return with control and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This exercise targets the glutes to build hip strength, balance, and muscle definition.

name: Standing Donkey Kick
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal, with your working leg positioned just beyond the end of Tonal's arm. Shift your weight into your standing leg and hold onto Tonal for support. Bend the knee of your working leg, raising your heel under your hips. Then, straighten your leg, driving your heel back like you're closing a door with the bottom of your foot. Keep your chest tall and hips steady. Return with control and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This glute-focused movement boosts hip extension power and strengthens the posterior chain, which is key for running, lifting, and posture.

name: Standing Hip Abduction
descriptionHow: Stand perpendicular to Tonal with your outside, working leg connected to Tonal's arm. Shift your weight to your inside leg while holding onto Tonal lightly for support. Lift your working leg straight out to the side like you're pushing a door open with the outside edge of your foot. Keep your chest tall and hips level. Return and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This movement activates the glute medius and outer thigh muscles, improving hip stability, balance, and injury resilience—especially for runners and lifters.

name: Standing Single Leg Hamstring Curl
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal with your working leg in line with Tonal's arm. Holding on to the trainer for balance, softly bend your standing leg and curl the heel of your working leg in toward your glute. Avoid locking out your knee at the end of the movement to maintain tension. Lower with control and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This movement isolates the hamstrings to build leg strength, support knee stability, and improve balance and athletic power.

name: Standing Straight Leg Glute Kickback
descriptionHow: Stand facing Tonal with your working leg in line with Tonal's arm. Holding onto Tonal for support, shift your weight into your standing leg. Extend your working leg straight back behind you, aiming your heel toward the back wall. Maintain a straight line from head to heel. Return with control and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This move targets your glutes, helping improve hip stability, posture, and lower-body strength while enhancing muscle tone through isolated extension.

name: Standing Leg Extension
descriptionHow: Stand perpendicular to Tonal, positioned in between the arms with your working leg connected to the arm behind you. Holding onto Tonal lightly for balance, bend your working knee to lift your heel behind you just past 90 degrees. Straighten your leg, extending your heel toward the floor while keeping your thighs parallel. Return with control and repeat on the same side.
descriptionWhy: This exercise strengthens your quadriceps and supports healthy knee function, aiding in walking, climbing, and overall lower-body endurance.
